Author: dhimes
Content: Interesting to see how this will play out.  Professors are divided on the issue of how much to bare. There are those who feel that not being seen as an infallible guru takes away their prestige--even to the point of advising other instructors to never admit they don't know something.  Others, like me, take a more "I'm human too" approach.

Author: brk
Content: You really don't though, a few minutes is all that is needed for something that cooks quick like fish.

Author: jmvdpol
Content:
"groups of 8 work well; by 20 they're getting hard to manage; and a group of 50 is really unwieldy."

Amen. I like to state here my 2nd law of corporate's immutable entropy: individual intelligence times somewhere between 50 to 150 leads to collective stupidity. It's a rather sharp s-curve, really.

Great stuff Mr. Graham, thanks.\nJurgen

Author: bosshog
Title: The perfect virtual community - facebook lost it

Author: dhimes
Content: That's why when you get someone like Steve Jobs to give you advice, whether you like it or not you listen to it without being defensive.  It's very tough to do (from customers and potentials too); it's easy to say to your self, "well, they just don't get it."  But that's foolish.

Author: tim2
Content: Making an open source project into a startup seems like a very long road. I don't know this particular area (finance messaging) though.

Author: marvin
Content: You should compare your health care expenses to what people in countries with state-paid health care pay. In Norway, the government or local government end up with about 60% (probably a bit more) of the money a regular employee earns. I think something in the realm of 10% of that money goes to health care (stitching together these numbers is a bit tricky, because our health care doesn't pay for exactly the same things your health insurance does)

Author: cperciva
Content:
I'm guessing that there's a typo in the title... I imagine "a gay in a garage" is just as likely to be successful as any other guy in a garage.

But to answer the question: If you're going to get into a fight with an elephant, the trick is to avoid being directly in front of it when it charges. Yes, you can compete -- but compete by doing something different, not by duplicating what they're already doing.
